awd_titl_txt: Multidimensionality of Race and Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
As race and ethnic diversity in the U.S. continue to increase, it is vital to understand the forces that perpetuate intergroup conflict, disparities in life outcomes, and social segregation. Many of the interpersonal processes that contribute to intergroup divisions and conflict begin during adolescence. The teen years are a critical point in the life course when identity and beliefs surrounding race/ethnic groups begin to emerge and crystallize. Concurrently, youth attention shifts away from family toward school and peer contexts that, unlike family, teens have a role in choosing. These contexts provide opportunities to get to know people from different backgrounds and, under the right conditions, can reduce negative beliefs and overcome stereotypes about other race/ethnic groups, allowing genuine cross-group friendships to develop. The leads to the questions: how do the right conditions come about? In diverse settings, what leads adolescents to choose diverse friends or join diverse activities, versus rejecting out-group friendships and peers? This project investigates how race/ethnic identity and other factors affect social relationships and, in turn, how social relationships affect ethnic-racial identity. The project will then examine how these interrelated processes contribute to patterns of race/ethnic segregation within social settings. These findings help to understand how adolescents gain experience with diverse friends and in diverse activities that produce positive intergroup contact attitudes, thus assisting school and community leaders in promoting positive social relationships during this critical time in the life course.

The goals of the current study are to investigate: (1) how various dimensions of race (i.e., ethnic-racial identity, perceived race, and phenotypic features) manifest during friend selection; (2) how friendships and extracurricular activity co-participation promote one another, and their bidirectional association with dimensions of race; and (3) the relative contribution of the aforementioned selection and peer influence mechanisms to observed race/ethnic segregation in friendships and activities. This latter step helps answer the question of how consequential different pathways are for reproducing race/ethnic segregation. To address these aims this project will consider two peer contexts: school-based friendship networks and extracurricular activities. The project uses longitudinal data on more than 3,000 students and 200 activities from two racially diverse high schools originally included in the Teen Identity Development and Education Study (TIDES). Friendship networks and ethnic-racial identity were measured with surveys during three in-school data collection waves. Activity participation and phenotypic features will be coded from school yearbooks. The project's statistical analysis uses a stochastic actor-oriented model to examine the co-evolution of friendship networks, extracurricular activity participation, and individual ethnic-racial development. Findings from the project will inform sociological theories regarding inter-group cooperation, minority identity, and the role of school settings in promoting adolescent development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research integrates ecological models of development with social network theories of friendship to represent how individuals select into peer and group settings, which in turn shape their beliefs and attitudes. We use this comprehensive model of person-environment selection dynamics to evaluate how various theorized mechanisms contribute to ethnoracial segregation. We provide a mechanistic account of how micro-level friendship and extracurricular activity dynamics combine with adolescent ethnic-racial development to produce macro-level patterns of ethnoracial segregation within social contexts. The project extends theories of network dynamics and identity development in three new directions by articulating and testing: (a) the bidirectional interrelations between multiple facets of race as related to friendship, with a particular focus on friend selection based on phenotypic characteristics, as well as distinguishing self-classification from known racial ancestry, (b) the endogenous role of the group (i.e., ECA) context in structuring social networks and the development of racial identity, and (c) the multiple pathways through which these processes cumulate to produce system-wide patterns of ethnoracial segregation. To facilitate these theoretical developments, we offer a practical method for gathering school-wide longitudinal data on student phenotype and contexts of activity participation.

Project findings can be classified based on each of the outcomes we investigate. Regarding friend selection, we find that the high school students we studied were about 1.5 times more likely to select same vs. cross-race friends and approximately twice as likely to befriend someone in the same extracurricular activity vs. befriending someone outside the activity. Our study also included a relatively high proportion of multiracial students (just over one-third). For these students, we were able to differentiate the multiple racial groups in their ancestry from the singular racial group they self-classified into when asked. We found that multiracial students drew upon both their ethnoracial heritage and their current racial identity when choosing friends, with these effects of comparable magnitude. Net of race/ethnicity, students were more likely to befriend peers who were similar in phenotype (i.e., skin tone). Turning to extracurricular activities as an outcome, we found that adolescents tended to participate in the same activities as their friends (i.e., peer influence on activity participation). Net of friend influence, students selected activities with more participants who shared their race/ethnic background and academic performance, but not socioeconomic status. However, we do not find evidence to suggest that these forces contribute to racial segregation within activities. Lastly, turning to outcomes related to race, we find that multiracial students were likely to self-classify their race based on how well they matched the phenotypically prototypical member of that race. Moreover, we found evidence of peer influence on race self-classification in that multiracial students were likely to claim a racial identity that matched their friends? self-classification. We also find that attitudes toward intergroup contact are more strongly affected by friends attitudes then by intergroup friendships.

This research has had significant impacts in education and training at the undergraduate and graduate levels and the inclusion of underrepresented groups. Students have been involved in every aspect of the project and have gained training in archival data collection and coding, innovative strategies for analyzing longitudinal social network data, and exposure to theories of ethnic-racial identity development and intergroup relations. Students have been and will continue to be involved as co-authors for conference presentations and publications. The project has served as the basis for two PhD dissertations and one undergraduate honor?s thesis. As we continue this research and disseminate project findings we expect they will have broader impacts on intergroup relations by highlighting the forces that affect intergroup attitudes and contact within friendships and activities, which can inform programs designed to improve intergroup relations.
